School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Shihezi University Shihezi Xinjiang 832000 China At present, the acetylene acetic acid reaction catalysts studied are metal catalysts. Whether there are non-metallic materials that can catalyze the reaction is very worth exploring. In this study, we used density functional theory (DFT) to calculate the feasibility of preparing vinyl acetate (VAc) on four CN non-metallic materials (C2N, C3N, C4N and C5N) under the reaction conditions of 1 atm, 393.15–493.15 K at B3LYP/6-31G(d, p) level. It is found that after considering the reaction temperature, only C2N and C3N show good adsorption capacity for acetylene and acetic acid, and C3N has stronger adsorption capacity for reactants. After that, we calculated and simulated the reaction process of acetylene acetic acid reaction catalyzed by four CN materials. It is found that among the four CN materials, the energy barrier of the reaction rate control step of C3N is the lowest (the free energy barrier of the rate control step is only 30.57 kcal/mol at 393.15 K), and the interior of CN non-metallic materials has higher activity than the boundary of hydrogen sealing. We also found that the reaction process on CN non-metallic material is consistent with the acid catalysis mechanism, which shows that the non-metallic catalyst is theoretically feasible for catalyzing the acetic acid acidification of acetylene, and the two-dimensional C3N material is likely to be a potential non-metallic catalyst for the preparation of vinyl acetate by acetylene gas phase method. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acetylene Acetic acid Vinyl acetate Nonmetallic catalyst CN material 1 Introduction Vinyl acetate (VAc) is a colorless flammable liquid with a sweet ether odor. As a widely used organic chemical raw material, VAc is one of the 50 chemical raw materials with the largest production volume in the world [1–3]. Several important polymers, such as polyvinyl alcohol [4,5], polyacrylonitrile [6,7], ethylene–vinyl acetate copolymer resin [8], polyvinyl acetate emulsion and resin, [9] and copolymer resin [10], are based on VAc as a raw material. It is widely used in fiber synthesis, leather processing, coating, soil improvement, and other fields. As a widely used chemical raw material, VAc is produced by the acetylene or ethylene methods [11]. Compared with acetylene method, ethylene method has more mature application technology and better performance in industrial production. However, acetylene process is more competitive than ethylene process in China, India and other countries where coal resources are abundant but oil resources are scarce. At present, the production process of acetylene preparation of vinyl acetate mainly relies on zinc acetate catalyst [12,13]. But the traditional zinc acetate catalyst has some disadvantages such as rapid activity decline, low productivity and short catalyst life. Precious metal (Pb, Au, etc.) catalysts [3,14,15] have limited resources and high prices, so it is difficult to be applied in large-scale industry. Compared with metal catalysts, non-metallic catalysts have the characteristics of abundant reserves, simple preparation, environmental friendliness and high stability [16]. In addition, nonmetallic catalysts have been proved to have good catalytic activity in some fields of efficient utilization of acetylene [17–19]. Therefore, it is of great significance to investigate whether nonmetallic catalysts have catalytic activity for acetylene acetate reaction. Monolayer graphene has been the focus of scientific research since it was developed by Geim and Novoselov in 2004 [20]. Because of graphene's limited number of active sites, its nonmetallic catalytic activity and selectivity are not satisfactory. However, when examining the derivatives on the basis of graphene, it can be seen that they demonstrate impressive nonmetallic catalytic performance, which provides a direction for further research into the acetylation of acetylene over nonmetallic catalysts [21,22]. To compensate for the defects, heteroatom doping is a novel and efficient method, such as nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and boron (B) doping [23,24]. In recent years, CN catalysts have been extensively studied by researchers, and two dimensional CN materials have gradually become a research hotspot in the field of catalysis, including C2N, [25–27] C3N, [28–30] C4N, [31–33] C5N, [34,35] and other nonmetallic CN catalysts. Although there is no report on the reaction of acetylene and acetic acid catalyzed by CN materials, CN non-metallic catalysts have shown good catalytic effect in some areas of efficient utilization of acetylene [36–38]. This also provides corresponding support for further study on whether non-metallic CN materials have catalytic activity for the reaction of acetic acid and acetylene. Herein, based on the reaction conditions of acetylene gas phase method, the catalytic performance of different C/N ratios catalysts (C2N, C3N, C4N, C5N) at the temperature of 393.15–493.15 K was investigated under the pressure of 1 atm. Firstly, we constructed and optimized the initial structures of C2N, C3N, C4N and C5N catalysts, studied the adsorption and Co-adsorption process of acetylene and acetic acid on the catalysts, and discussed the adsorption effects of different adsorption sites. Based on the co-adsorption structure, the transition state structure of the reaction process was found and the reaction energy barrier of the reaction rate control step was calculated. The effects of temperature on the catalytic properties were compared, and the reasons for the differences of catalytic properties of four CN materials were further speculated. The results show that with the increase of reaction temperature, the adsorption capacity of catalyst for acetylene and acetic acid decreases, and the energy barrier of reaction rate control step increases slightly. Due to the different CN ratio and basic structure of the catalyst, the adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid on different catalysts will change greatly, the order of adsorption capacity of the four catalysts for reactants is C3N > C2N > C4N > C5N. Under the condition of 393.15–493.15 K, the adsorption process of C2N is exothermic adsorption when the reaction temperature is low, and gradually becomes endothermic adsorption with the increase of temperature. The adsorption of C3N to reactants is exothermic. The adsorption of C4N and C5N to reactants is endothermic. In addition, there are some differences in the catalytic capacity of the four catalysts, the order of catalytic capacity of the four catalysts for reaction is C3N > C2N > C5N > C4N. The reaction energy barrier of C3N is the lowest, 30.57 kcal/mol at 393.15 K. We found that the catalytic performance of C3N is better than that of C5N with similar structure, and C3N and C5N structures have two reaction paths, respectively, while C2N and C4N structures with holes not only have lower catalytic performance than C3N, but also only one reaction path. Among the four catalysts we studied, C3N not only has a stronger adsorption capacity for reactants, but also shows a lower reaction energy barrier, which is a potential catalyst for the preparation of ethylene acetate by acetylene gas phase method. 2 Computational methods All the studies in this paper were conducted using the Becke, 3-parameter, Lee–Yang–Parr (B3LYP) functional of density functional theory (DFT) [39,40], and calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 [41] software package. The B3LYP nonlocal correlation functional with the 6-31G(d,p) [42] basis set was applied to C, N, O, and H atoms. The DFT-D3 method [43] was used to calculate the density functional dispersion correction. Considering the influence of reaction temperature and base group superposition error, the relative energy of all optimized configurations along the reaction path is the Sum of electronic and thermal Free Energies(G) at the same optimization level, and no symmetry constraints were assumed in the geometrical optimization. Gibbs free energy can be calculated as follows Eq. (1): (1) G = E ( e l e c ) + Z P E + E ( v i b ) + E ( r o l ) + E ( t r a n s ) + R T − T S Where G is the Gibbs free energy of the system, E(elec) is the total electronic energy of the system, ZPE is the zero point energies of the system. E(vib), E(rol) and E(transl) are the vibrational energy, rotational energy and translational energy of the system respectively, and S is the entropy of the system. The calculation formulas of entropy (s) and zero point energy (ZPE) are shown in equations Eqs. (2) and (3). In addition, in order to explore the influence of different temperatures, we used Shermo code [44] to calculate the Gibbs free energy (G) of each structure at different reaction temperatures. (2) S = N k B + N k B l n ( q ( V , T ) N ) + N k B T ( ∂ l n q ∂ T ) V (3) Z P E = ∑ h v 2 In this work, all structural optimization and transition state calculation are carried out on the basis of the same calculation level, and the state of the optimized stable point is verified by calculating the harmonic vibration frequency. The stable point is the point where the force is zero on the potential energy surface, which may be either a minimum or a saddle point. The minimum is minimal in all directions of the potential energy surface, that is, the structure of reactants, products or intermediates in the reaction process. The saddle point is minimal in some directions, but maximal in one direction, that is, the so-called transition state structure. Based on the above theory, we verify that the optimized geometry has no frequency through harmonic vibration frequency, and all eigenvalues of its force constant matrix are positive, so as to ensure that the structure is a stable minimum point on the electron energy plane. Similarly, by calculating the resonant frequency of the transition state structure, it is found that there is an imaginary frequency, and the eigenvalue of the force constant matrix has only a negative value. However, the correct transition state(Ts) does not only have a virtual frequency, and the vibration direction of this virtual frequency is related to the desired reactants and products. A better way is to judge whether the reactant products are related to the obtained transition state through the calculation of the intrinsic reaction coordinators (IRC) [45,46]. Finally, we calculate the intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC) of the transition state structure, and verify the reactants and products connected at both ends of Ts, so as to determine the correct transition state structure. During this study, the method of calculating adsorption energy and CO adsorption energy is shown in Eqs. (4) and (5). The process of calculating the energy barrier of reaction rate control step on each reaction path adopts the method of finding rate control step proposed by Murdoch [47] (4) Δ G a d s = G a d s − s t a t e − ( G C 2 H 2 / C H 3 C O O H + G C a t a l y s t ) (5) Δ G C o − a d s = G C o − a d s − s t a t e − ( G C 2 H 2 + G C H 3 C O O H + G C a t a l y s t ) where Gads-state and GCo-ads-state represent the total Gibbs free energy of the adsorbed substance and catalyst, and GCatalyst, GC2H2 , and GCH3COOH are the Gibbs free energy of a single catalyst and a single reactant, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometries of the reactants In this study, the catalysts used included C2N, C3N, C4N, and C5N, and the reactants included acetylene and acetic acid molecules. Fig. 1 shows their optimized geometry. Fig. 1(a) shows the structure of C2N, a two-dimensional single-layer structure composed of a benzene ring connected by N atoms. C2N can also be considered a honeycomb lattice, composed of N atoms connected to a benzene ring with large cavities at the center [48]. Fig. 1(b) shows the C3N structure, a two-dimensional C and N crystal without cavities. In the honeycomb structure of the C3N monolayer, there are two types of hexagonal rings, a CN ring consisting of two N and four C atoms and a ring consisting of six carbon atoms; both the C and N atoms demonstrate D6h symmetry [29]. Fig. 1(c) shows a monolayer C4N structure. C4N structures are composed of alternating C–N hexagons and C–N pentagon–octagon–pentagons. C–C and C–N bonds can be single or double bonds, indicating that the electrons are well localized in the ring and the structure has a certain stability [49]. Fig. 1(d) shows a monolayer C5N structure. C5N is made up of a C atom on a benzene ring replaced by an N atom. The C5N layer configuration has hexagonal symmetry with a P 6 ¯ 2m space group [35]. The support information Table S1 describes the bond length between different atoms and the charge carried by each atom in the C2N, C3N, C4N and C5N structures in Fig. 1. The density-of-states (DOS) of the catalyst was analyzed using the Mutiwfn software package [50]. (a–d) in Fig. 2 are the state density diagrams of C2N, C3N, C4N and C5N, respectively. The corresponding frontier molecular orbital was analyzed, and the contributions of the P orbital of carbon-atom and the P orbital of nitrogen-atoms to the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) in different catalysts were compared. For C2N, C3N, C4N, and C5N, the density-of-state diagram shows that the contribution of the P orbitals of carbon-atoms to the highest occupied molecular orbital(HOMO) and the lowest unoccated molecular orbital(LUMO) is greater than that of the P orbitals of nitrogen-atoms. The levels of HOMO, LUMO and HOMO-LUMO gap are shown in Fig. 2(e), and specific data are shown in Table S2 of Support information. According to the frontier orbital theory proposed by Fukui et al. [51], the value of HOMO-LUMO energy gap between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccued molecular orbital (LUMO) reflects the ability of the electron to transition from occupied orbital to vacant orbital, so it represents the strength of a molecule's ability to participate in chemical reactions to a certain extent [52]. At the same time, the larger the HOMO-LUMO gap, the less likely the electron transition is to occur, and the more stable the molecule is [53]. By comparing the HOMO-LUMO gap in Fig. 2(e), we find that the HOMO-LUMO gap of C3N is much smaller than that of the other three CN materials, indicating that electrons on C3N are easier to transition from occupied orbit to vacant orbit. Therefore, we speculate that C3N may have the best catalytic activity among the four CN materials. Before studying the reaction process, we carried out electrostatic potential analysis on the catalyst. Fig. 3 shows the molecular electrostatic potential diagrams of the C2N, C3N, C4N, and C5N catalysts. Blue and red represent positive and negative charges, respectively. The darker the color, the more concentrated the corresponding charge. We found that as the proportion of C/N ratios on the catalyst increased, the charge transfer inside the catalyst became more obvious. By analyzing the molecular electrostatic potential of the four catalysts, we were better able to identify the adsorption and reaction sites. Since acetylene acetate reaction is electrophilic, we predict that where the negative charge accumulates will be the site of the reaction, and based on this prediction, we carried out the next research. 3.2 Adsorption of C2H2 and CH3COOH over catalysts First, the adsorption of single CH3COOH and C2H2 molecules on C2N, C3N, C4N and C5N at 393.15 K was analyzed. The different adsorption sites were calculated (The adsorption structures and adsorption energies are shown in Table S3 of Support information), and the most stable CH3COOH and C2H2 adsorption structure to be adsorbed on the surface of CN catalyst were determined, as shown in Fig. 4 . By comparing the molecular electrostatic potential of the four catalysts in Fig. 3, we found that the adsorption sites of acetylene and acetic acid were greatly related to the positive and negative values and distribution of molecular electrostatic potential on the catalyst surface. In Fig. 4(a) and (b), the adsorption sites of acetylene and acetic acid molecules on C2N are the holes with obvious negative charge accumulation on C2N, and both acetylene and acetic acid molecules are adsorbed in a way that hydrogen atoms are close to the center of the holes and almost perpendicular to the catalyst plane. In Fig. 4(c) and (d), the adsorption sites of acetylene and acetic acid molecules on C3N are also concentrated at the positions with negative charge accumulation. Although the charge transfer on C4N and C5N is not as good as that on C2N and C3N, the relatively stable adsorption site is still near the negative charge aggregation position on the catalyst. This indicates that the adsorption of acetylene and acetic acid on CN catalyst may be related to the accumulation of negative charge caused by charge transfer between atoms on the catalyst after N atoms doping. After that, we investigated the adsorption properties of the catalysts at 393.15–493.15 K with a temperature gradient of 10 K. Fig. 5 (a) and (b) show the fitting curves of adsorption energy of CN catalysts for acetylene and acetic acid at 393.15 K to 493.15 K, respectively. As can be seen from the Fig. 5, the order of adsorption capacity of the four CN catalysts for acetylene is C3N > C2N > C4N > C5N, and the order of adsorption capacity for acetic acid is C3N > C2N > C5N > C4N. With the change of reaction temperature, the adsorption capacity of the four CN catalysts to reactants decreased to a certain extent. Detailed data of adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid at different temperatures are shown in Table S4 of Support information. To further study the reaction of acetylene and acetic acid molecules on the catalyst, their Co-adsorption structure was investigated. In Fig. 6 , (a–d) are the optimal adsorption configurations optimized on C2N, C3N, C4N and C5N under the reaction conditions of 1 atm and 393.15 K, respectively. Fig. 6(e) shows the adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid on four CN catalysts at 393.15–493.15 K. It can be seen from Fig. 6(e) that the adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid on different catalysts changed greatly with the change of catalyst C/N ratios. At 393.15–493.15 K, the co-adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid on C2N is negative at 393.15 K, and becomes positive gradually with the increase of temperature. The Co-adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid on C3N is negative, and the Co-adsorption energy on C4N and C5N is positive. By comparing the adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid, it can be found that C2Nand C3N are more conducive to the transition from single adsorption to Co-adsorption in thermodynamics, while C4N and C5N need to absorb higher energy before the transition from single adsorption to co-adsorption. Detailed data of adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid at different temperatures are shown in Table S4 of Support information. In addition, we also compare the energy of single adsorption energy and Co-adsorption energy, and find that the sum of single adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid molecules on C2N and C3N is greater than their co-adsorption energy, while the sum of single adsorption energy of acetylene and acetic acid molecules on C4N and C5N is less than their co-adsorption energy. This difference may be caused by the different N doping ratio in the catalyst. Because the adsorption site on the catalyst has a certain adsorption capacity for the two reactant molecules, when a single molecule is first adsorbed on a site of C2N and C3N catalyst to form a stable structure, it will inhibit the adsorption of the second reactant, resulting in acetylene and acetic acid molecules at the site of mutual exclusion. The repulsion between the reactants causes the adsorption energy of co-adsorption to be less than the sum of single adsorption. For C4N and C5N, due to the decrease of N doping ratio, the interatomic charge transfer on the catalyst is not strong enough, so that C4N and C5N have almost no adsorption capacity for the reactants, and even the single reactants need to absorb certain energy from the outside to form a stable adsorption structure. There will not be corresponding competition between the two reactant molecules on the catalyst, and there will be a certain interaction between acetylene and acetic acid molecules to form a stable structure between the two molecules and the catalyst. Therefore, the sum of the single adsorption energies on C4N and C5N will be less than co-adsorption. In addition, we draw IRI diagram (Fig. S1 of Supporting information) through Multiwfn and VMD program [54], and find that this interaction between adsorbate and surface in stable Co-adsorption structure is van der Waals force. 3.3 Reaction mechanism of acetylene acetate reaction catalyzed by C2N, C3N, C4N, and C5N There are many studies [55–59] on the reaction mechanism of acetylene gas-phase production of vinyl acetate, but there is no unified view on the reaction mechanism of acetylene vinegar acidification. Presently, the three mechanisms most widely accepted by researchers are the acid catalysis mechanism, the Kripylo mechanism, and the Furukawa mechanism. See Supporting information Fig. S2 for the specific reaction process and flow chart of the above three mechanisms. In these studies, Dong et al. [58] Studied the reaction mechanism of acetylene and acetic acid catalyzed by zinc acetate based on three reaction mechanisms, and found that Furukawa mechanism has obvious defects, while kripylo's mechanism and acid catalysis mechanism are feasible, and the effect of kripylo's mechanism is better for zinc acetate catalyst. Miyazawa [60] found that using V2O5-ZnO, Fe2O3-ZnO two-component oxides, 24ZnO·8Cr2O3·V2O5 and 16ZnO·32Fe2O3·V2O5 as active components, the catalytic activity is much higher than that of industrial catalysts at high temperature (250 °C), but its high cost Due to the disadvantages of high reaction temperature and rapid deactivation, such catalysts are still in the stage of laboratory research. Hu et al. [61] also found ZnO-N-C catalyst with excellent performance, which can reach 100% within ten hours of reaction, and the content of by-products is low, but it also has the problem of rapid deactivation. However, it is impossible to explain the source of activity of these non zinc acetate catalysts if Furukawa mechanism and Kripylo mechanism are used. Therefore, we believe that the acid catalysis mechanism is very likely to be a suitable mechanism for non zinc acetate catalysts. In the acid catalysis mechanism, the reaction is through the formation of vinyl cations. The action of the catalyst leads to acetic acid molecular dissociation, the generation of H+ and acetic acid with ions (Eq. (6)); the addition of acetylene molecules to produce vinyl cations (Eq. (7)); the vinyl cations then react with the acetic acid and anions to produce VAc (Eq. (8)). The equations for the reactions are as follows: (6) CH3COOH → CH3COO− + H+ (7) CHCH + H+ → CH2=C+H (8) CH2=C+H + CH3COO− → CH2=CHOOCCH3 In addition, Wu et al. [62] showed that activated carbon alone or zinc acetate alone is inactive. Obviously, the role of carbon is not only to provide a dispersion medium, zinc acetate, but also likely to play other roles in the catalytic process. In this regard, we have carried out corresponding theoretical research on the reaction of acetylene and acetic acid on non-metallic CN materials according to the acid catalysis mechanism, so as to explore the possibility of non-metallic materials catalyzing the reaction of acetylene and acetic acid. All the calculation results in the subsequent papers are based on the reaction conditions at 1 atm and 393.15 K. The specific data of the reaction process from 393.15–493.15 K with 10 K as the temperature gradient at 1atm are given in the Support information. 3.3.1 Reaction mechanism over C2N The black paths in Fig. 7 shows the detailed reaction process and energy changes of acetylene and acetic acid over C2N catalysts. Based on the mechanism of acid catalytic reaction, when vinyl acetate is generated between acetylene and acetic acid molecules on C2N, the O−H bond on the carboxyl group of acetic acid molecule will break and generate CH3COO− and H+, and the H+ from acetic acid dissociation will attack CHCH. During the attack of H+, the CC triple bond of CHCH will break to form C=C double bond, and then CH2=C+H will be formed. Finally, The O− on CH3COO− attacks the C+ on CH2=C+H to form vinyl acetate(VAc). The transition state structure of this reaction process is the configuration with the highest energy when H+ attacks CHCH, as shown in Ts1 in Fig. 7. Through the harmonic vibration frequency analysis of the transition state structure(Ts1), it was found that the Ts1 structure had only one virtual frequency (−1407.57 cm−1), and the vibration direction of this frequency was related to the tensile vibration of H+ disintegrated by CH3COOH between CH3COO− and C2H2, See support information S1 for resonance frequency data of all transition state structures in this paper. The reaction energy barrier from the Co-ads to the Ts1 is 33.09 kcal/mol. The intrinsic reaction coordinators (IRC) of the Ts1 structure was calculated, and the Co-ads and Fs of Ts1 connection were verified, which also indicated that there was no additional intermediate in the reaction process. Due to the influence of C2N catalyst, the generated vinyl acetate is adsorbed near the C2N hole, as shown in Fig. 7 Fs. We desorbed vinyl acetate on the catalyst, and the product structure was VAc as shown in Fig. 7, with a desorption energy of 0.24 kcal/mol. By comparing the whole reaction process, it is found that the rate-control step of the reaction is from the Co-ads to the Ts1, and its rate-control step energy barrier is 33.09 kcal/mol. Energy data at other reaction temperatures are shown in Support information Table S4. 3.3.2 Reaction mechanism over C3N Path 1 on C3N: The red and blue paths in Fig. 7 show the two detailed reaction processes and energy changes of acetylene and acetic acid over a C3N catalyst. In path 1, the Co-adsorption structure (Co-ads) forms the CH2=CH* complex (p1-Im1) with the C atom on C3N through the transition state structure (p1-Ts1). The reaction energy barrier for this step is 35.43 kcal/mol. As shown in Fig. 7, the p1-Ts1 is the highest energy configuration in the formation of CH2=CH* complex, in which acetylene molecules undergo obvious deformation and tend to approach C3N. Through the harmonic vibration frequency analysis, it was found that the p1-Ts1 structure had only one virtual frequency (−540.71 cm−1). The vibration of this frequency is mainly related to the close vibration between the C atoms of C2H2 and the C atoms of C3N, and there is also a certain degree of vibration between the H atom of the carboxyl group of CH3COOH and C2H2. Then the intermediate structure (p1-Im1) was determined by IRC calculation, and the correctness of p1-Ts1 was verified. Subsequently, the CH2=CH* complex in the p1-Im1 will decompose to form CH2=C+H and C3N catalyst, and CH2=C+H will react with CH3COO− to form vinyl acetate (VAc). In this reaction process, the reaction system will pass through the highest energy state (p1-Ts2), as shown in Fig. 7. In order to generate ethylene acetate, the p1-Im1 needs to absorb 44.54 kcal/mol energy to over the saddle point of potential energy surface(p1-Ts2). Similarly, Through the harmonic vibration frequency analysis, it was found that the p1-Ts2 had only one virtual frequency (−145.50 cm−1), and the vibration direction of this frequency is related to the tensile vibration of CH2=C+H between C3N and CH3COO−. In addition, the correctness of p1-Ts2 connecting p1-Im1 and Fs was verified by IRC. Finally, VAc was desorbed at an energy of 11.19 kcal / mol. By comparing the energy changes in the whole reaction process, we found that the process from the p1-Im1 to the p1-Ts2 is the rate-controlled step of acetylene acetate reaction on C3N, and the rate-controlled step energy barrier is 44.54 kcal/mol. Path 2 on C3N: In path 2, the O−H bond on the carboxyl group of acetic acid molecule breaks to form CH3COO− and H+, and the H+ after acetic acid dissociates attacks CHCH to form CH2=C+H, CH2=C+H reacts with CH3COO− to form VAc1. The transition state structure (p2-Ts1) of this process is shown in Fig. 7, and the reaction energy barrier is 30.57 kcal/mol. This structure is very similar to the transition state structure of C2N, that is, the highest energy configuration in the process of CH3COOH dissociating H+ attacking CHCH. Through the harmonic vibration frequency analysis, it was found that the p2-Ts1 structure had only one virtual frequency (−792.40 cm−1), and the vibration direction of this frequency was related to the tensile vibration of H+ disintegrated by CH3COOH between CH3COO− and C2H2. However, we found that the product VAc1 on C3N has a different structure from the product VAc on C2N (as shown in Fig. 7). By comparing the energy of the two structures, it is found that the energy of VAc structure is lower than that of VAc1 structure, and the structure is more stable. This indicates that VAc1 structure (p2-Im1) generated on C3N is only an intermediate structure, so we explored the conversion process of VAc1 to VAc on this basis. It was found that the reaction energy barrier was as high as 45.97 kcal/mol due to the influence of catalyst when VAc1 was converted to VAc on C3N. Its transition state structure is shown in p2-Ts2 in Fig. 7. The p2-Ts2 has only one virtual frequency (−686.80 cm−1), and the vibration direction of this frequency is related to the tensile vibration of CH2=C+H between two O atoms of CH3COO−. The p2-Im1 passes through the p2-Ts2 and then transforms into the Fs. Finally, the Fs absorbs 11.19 kcal/mol and makes vinyl acetate (VAc) desorbed from C3N. In addition, we also found that if the product VAc1 was desorbed on C3N first, its desorption energy was 10.38 kcal/mol. VAc1 only needs 2.31 kcal/mol energy to cross the transition state structure (p2-Ts3) and generate VAc without the influence of catalyst. The p2-Ts3 has only one virtual frequency (−100.31 cm−1), and the vibration direction of this frequency is related to the torsional vibration of vinyl acetate (VAc) itself. At the reaction temperature of 393.15 K, the energy barrier of 2.31 kcal/mol is almost negligible. If this energy barrier is ignored, it can be considered that VAc1 is not an intermediate structure, but VAc that has undergone certain deformation under the action of CN catalyst, and the final product VAc is obtained after desorption. At this time, p2-Ts2 can also be considered as a redundant process. We confirmed the correctness of the transition state through the intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) in all the above processes. By comparing the energy barrier sizes of different reaction paths, we found that the optimal reaction path existed in path 2, and the reaction energy barrier of its speed control step was 30.57 kcal/mol. Energy data at other reaction temperatures are shown in Support information Table S4. 3.3.3 Reaction mechanism over C4N The reaction process of acetylene and acetic acid on C4N is very similar to path 2 of C3N, but because the adsorption process of C4N to reactants is endothermic, it requires more energy for the reactants on C4N to jump over the transition state structure (Ts1). The reactants need to absorb 35.02 kcal/mol energy from the initial state to the Co-ads and then to the Ts1. The transition state structure on C4N is shown in Ts1 in Fig. 8 , the Ts1 has only one virtual frequency (−826.82 cm−1), and the vibration direction of this frequency was related to the tensile vibration of H+ disintegrated by CH3COOH between CH3COO− and C2H2. Like C3N, the intermediate structure (Im1) is formed after the Ts1, and the product on Im1 is VAc1. In this regard, VAc1 was desorbed based on the reaction process of C4N, and its desorption energy was -2.22 kcal/mol. VAc1 was converted into VAc after absorbing 2.31 kcal/mol energy and jumping over the Ts2. Similarly, we also calculated that VAc1 was directly converted into VAc on C4N, with an energy barrier of 46.91 kcal/mol. The specific structure of the transition state and the corresponding energy are shown in support information Fig. S3. Energy data at other reaction temperatures are shown in Support information Table S4. 3.3.4 Reaction mechanism over C5N Path 1 on C5N: As shown in Fig. 8, the reaction path 1 of acetylene and acetic acid on C5N is very similar to the path and energy of C4N. The adsorption process of C5N on the reactants is also endothermic, and the energy barrier from the initial structure to the transition state structure (p1-Ts1) is 34.60 kcal/mol. The transition state structure on C4N is shown in p1-Ts1 in Fig. 8, the p1-Ts1 has only one virtual frequency (−790.64 cm−1). In this regard, VAc1 was desorbed based on the reaction process of C5N, and its desorption energy was -1.68 kcal/mol. VAc1 was converted into VAc after absorbing 2.31 kcal/mol energy and jumping over the Ts2. Similarly, we also calculated that VAc1 was directly converted into VAc on C5N, with an energy barrier of 47.50 kcal/mol. The specific structure of the transition state and the corresponding energy are shown in support information Fig. S3. By comparing the energy changes of the whole reaction path, the rate-controlled energy barrier of this path is 34.60 kcal/mol. Energy data at other reaction temperatures are shown in Support information Table S4. Path 2 on C5N: In path 2, the Co-adsorption structure (Co-ads) forms the CH2=CH* complex (p2-Im1) with the C atom on C5N through the transition state structure (p2-Ts1). The reaction energy barrier for this step is 25.47 kcal/mol. As shown in p1-Ts1 in Fig. 8, through the harmonic vibration frequency analysis, it was found that the p2-Ts1 structure had only one virtual frequency (−475.42 cm−1). The vibration of this frequency is mainly related to the close vibration between the C atoms of C2H2 and the C atoms of C5N, and there is also a certain degree of vibration between the H atom of the carboxyl group of CH3COOH and C2H2. The IRC of the p1-Ts1 structure was calculated, and the correctness of the p2-Ts1 connected Co-adsorption structure (Co-ads) and intermediate structure (p2-Im1) was verified. It can be seen from p2-Im1 in Fig. 8, some torsion is required to continue the reaction between CH2=CH* and CH3COO−, so that the C atom connected to the C5N catalyst on CH2=CH* is closer to CH3COO−. The transition state structure of this process is shown as p2-Ts2 in Fig. 8, and the reaction energy barrier is 4.39 kcal/mol. the p2-Ts2 has only one virtual frequency (−121.05 cm−1). The p2-Im1 is twisted to form the p2-Im2, after which CH3COO− attacks the C atom connected to C5N on the vinyl to form vinyl acetate (VAc).The transition state structure of this process is shown as p2-Ts3 in Fig. 8, the p2-Ts3 has only one virtual frequency (−494.57 cm−1), and the vibrational side of this frequency corresponds to the offensive direction of CH3COO− towards the C atom on CH2=CH*. The reaction energy barrier of this process is 42.19 kcal/mol, much larger than that of other steps, so this step is also the speed control step of this reaction path. Finally, vinyl acetate (VAc) was desorbed on C5N with a desorption energy of -3.74 kcal/mol. Energy data at other reaction temperatures are shown in Support information Table S4. 3.3.5 Comparison of acetylene acetate reaction over CN catalysts By comparing the complete reaction processes of four CN materials, the first factor affecting the catalytic performance of CN non-metallic materials is the adsorption performance of materials for acetylene and acetic acid. Among the four CN materials, the adsorption energy of C4N and C5N to reactants is positive at 343.15–493.15 K; Although C2N shows certain adsorption, its spontaneous adsorption performance gradually decreases and disappears with the increase of reaction temperature. Therefore, C2N, C4N and C5N can not meet the conditions of catalyzing acetylene acetic acid reaction at higher temperature in experiment or industry. However, the adsorption free energy of C3N is still negative even if the reaction temperature increases to 493.15 K. In addition, compared with the other three catalysts, the energy barrier of the speed control step of the reaction of acetylene and acetic acid on C3N is also the lowest, which is the most potential catalyst among the four CN materials. The specific rate control steps and energy barriers of acetic acid acetylene reaction on four CN catalysts are shown in Table 1 . At 393.15 K and 1atm, the best reaction path on C3N is: The Co-adsorption structure absorbs 30.57 kcal/mol energy to jump over the p2-Ts1 to generate intermediate VAc1. After that, the system absorbs 10.38 kcal/mol energy to adsorb VAc1 on C3N for desorption. VAc1 absorbed 2.31 kcal/mol of energy to jump over the p2-Ts3 to form the product VAc. Based on the previous work, we calculated the activation energy of C3N with the best performance among the four CN materials and compared it with the experimental data. It is found that the activation energy(Ea) of acetylene acetic acid reaction on C3N is 26.52 kcal/mol, which still lags behind the activation energy of zinc acetate catalyst (19.164 kcal/mol). See Appendix A of Supporting information for details. In addition, we also roughly explored the catalytic performance of the boundary positions of the four CN materials. We found that the acetylene acetic acid reaction showed a large reaction energy barrier at the boundary position of hydrogen closure, which may not be the best reaction site. For details, see Appendix B of the Supporting information. 4 Conclusion Based on the reaction conditions of acetylene gas phase method, the reaction mechanism of four non-metallic catalysts with different C/N ratios for acetylene gas phase synthesis of VAc was studied by density functional theory. The order of the adsorption properties of the four catalysts to the reactants is C3N > C2N > C4N > C5N, and the order of the energy barrier of the rate control step in the catalytic process is C3N < C2N < C5N < C4N. We can see that C3N not only has the strongest adsorption capacity for reactants, but also has the lowest reaction energy barrier. In addition, the reaction process on CN non-metallic materials is also consistent with the acid catalysis mechanism, which shows that non-metallic catalysts are theoretically feasible for catalyzing acetylene acetate acidification. Although the activation energy of C3N catalyst is slightly higher than that of Zn/AC catalyst, C3N catalyst has lower price and wider range of raw materials. Compared with zinc acetate based catalyst, C3N will not have the problem of loss of active components (zinc acetate sublimation, zinc acetate thermal decomposition, etc.). Therefore, we predict that the two-dimensional C3N material is likely to be a potential non-metallic catalyst for the preparation of vinyl acetate by acetylene gas phase method. At the same time, we also hope that this conclusion can further promote the exploration of acetylene acetic acid acidification catalyzed by non-metallic CN materials, so as to break the monopoly of metal catalysts in acetylene acetic acid reaction. coredata.dc:description: At present, the acetylene acetic acid reaction catalysts studied are metal catalysts. Whether there are non-metallic materials that can catalyze the reaction is very worth exploring. In this study, we used density functional theory (DFT) to calculate the feasibility of preparing vinyl acetate (VAc) on four CN non-metallic materials (C2N, C3N, C4N and C5N) under the reaction conditions of 1 atm, 393.15–493.15 K at B3LYP/6-31G(d, p) level. It is found that after considering the reaction temperature, only C2N and C3N show good adsorption capacity for acetylene and acetic acid, and C3N has stronger adsorption capacity for reactants. After that, we calculated and simulated the reaction process of acetylene acetic acid reaction catalyzed by four CN materials. It is found that among the four CN materials, the energy barrier of the reaction rate control step of C3N is the lowest (the free energy barrier of the rate control step is only 30.57 kcal/mol at 393.15 K), and the interior of CN non-metallic materials has higher activity than the boundary of hydrogen sealing. We also found that the reaction process on CN non-metallic material is consistent with the acid catalysis mechanism, which shows that the non-metallic catalyst is theoretically feasible for catalyzing the acetic acid acidification of acetylene, and the two-dimensional C3N material is likely to be a potential non-metallic catalyst for the preparation of vinyl acetate by acetylene gas phase method.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical study on the synthesis of vinyl acetate from acetylene and acetic acid over nonmetallic catalysts with different carbon-nitrogen ratios
